summary: Honestly, it’s been a huge part of our lives and the only part we can remember (laughs) but it’s definitely like, you can feel a...
text:
Honestly, it’s been a huge part of our lives and the only part we can remember (laughs) but it’s definitely like, you can feel a chapter ending and a new one beginning,” Maisie pondered. “It’s necessary but really sad.”


Sophie chimed in: “It’s very bittersweet; it’s like we’re mourning death. It’s very interesting (pauses) it’s like the death of all characters, but not that our characters are dying (laughs), it’s the fact that we’re leaving these characters behind whenever we get to be them again. Yeah, it’s terrifying.

blog.name: itsgameofthronesimagines
blog.title: Valar Morghulis
blog.description:
Welcome to my Game of Thrones Imagines blog! Here: ships, requests, and fun are all welcome here! One-shots, drabbles, imagines, fake instagram, incorrect quotes, theories, debates, ships, smut are also allowed! Send writing prompt and ship requests! Boy, Girl, etc. Imagines. All sexual orientation and personal likes are welcomed here! Enjoy! (Requests: OPEN!)
Prompts: http://writingexercises.co.uk/dialogue-generator.php

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary:
Gendry: So, what's your type?
Arya: cute, brown hair, big muscles, stupid, playful
Gendry: That kinda sounds like me. Too bad...
body:
Gendry: So, what’s your type?

Arya: cute, brown hair, big muscles, stupid, playful

Gendry: That kinda sounds like me. Too bad I’m not a lord

Arya: …did I mention stupid?

Gendry: Aye

Arya: okay, just making sure

summary: Why do people assume that Arya’s ultimately destined to either die protecting someone or end up as a guard to Jon or Sansa or...
question: Why do people assume that Arya’s ultimately destined to either die protecting someone or end up as a guard to Jon or Sansa or both( with the two married). Why is it so hard to find people who believe that Arya could have a happy ending, as happy as is possible in Westeros given her journey?
answer:
Isn’t it obvious nonnie? Isn’t it obvious why some people are so miserly when it comes to Arya and her future? Why they pretend to mull over her storyline and say that the only rational conclusion they can think of is either a violent death or a life long oath of servitude?

Because deep down that’s what they want from her. To sacrifice herself for their fave or to give up everything that might have become of her. Why else would they ignore Arya’s wish to become a politician, a maestor or an architect? Why else would they parrot- “but she wanted to be a knight”? Why would they remain blind to the fact that each time Arya is forced to kill, she breaks a little inside? That she has ptsd? Tell me nonnie, wouldn’t being in the queensguard put her in harm’s way? Wouldn’t it add more to the trauma that she has already suffered?

I also think that one of the other major contributors to this thought process is Arya’s gender. Notice how her male counterparts are celebrated while she gets labelled as psychotic or as “just too damaged”? It’s plain and simple misogyny. To them she is an anomaly: they simply can’t understand how a girl who runs around in muddy dresses and is known to “collect scabs instead of dolls” ever like flowers. How someone who is so bad at singing and dancing can exude grace when she is waterdancing. How the hands which can barely crochet, fillet a fish and knead dough for an evening meal. How can a girl who is said to have mousey, tangled hair and a long face, ever grow into a wild beauty. How can one who is so rough around the edges be motherly enough to become an orphan child’s safe space. How can one who is so fierce ever be afraid or tired. How can a girl who refuses to mold herself according to the hypocritical norms of the society ever want to become someone’s forest love. How can she be someone’s heart?

Last of all, it can be that these people think that Arya Stark is disposable. They think that she is not important to the story of asoiaf at all. This is the reason why they barely acknowledge any of the “intellectual” lessons that Arya is receiving at the HoBaW, why they refuse to give merit to her leadership skills and the strong foreshadowing of ruling that is in her storyline. The reason why there are so many theories of her dying and living on in Nymeria as a pet exists.

Arya Stark is no one’s pet or servant. With how Grrm has written her, it’s clear that she has her own destiny to fulfill. She is after all one of the big fives and one of the original three characters from Grrm’s storyline. Her story is hardly going to conclude with her ending up as someone’s glorified bodyguard or as a sacrificial lamb.

tags: bc the show does not negate the books
and once the former is done
summary: i still believe that within the context of asoiaf as a war story arya stark is the most important and relevant character....
body:
i still believe that within the context of asoiaf as a war story arya stark is the most important and relevant character. countless children have been and continue to be exposed to poverty and violence as a result of warfare. they are the most vulnerable group and their stories are often not told. but with arya (the female pov with the highest pov count in this series) a huge focus was put directly on how warfare effects children and the lower class. and the narative doesnt demonize them. arya is not portrayed as a monster but a scared, loving, angry and incredibly brave child who is trying to navigate a world thats falling apart around her

and GoT - the most popular show in the world - had a chance to portray their story with empathy and respect too but they BLEW IT

summary: The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. Here’s what we know so far about the...
body:
The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. Here’s what we know so far about the season eight!

Image Source: Twitter

Along with everyone else in the world, we’re looking forward to the final season of Game of Thrones. It’s going to be six episodes of breathless action and a culmination of nine years of story-telling. It’s rare for a series to be able to have an endpoint in mind when they start, but that’s what Game of Thrones has done. Everything means something. If you rewatch, chances are you’ll find something new to support a theory you’re currently obsessing over.

Now, I said we’re looking forward to the final season, but when you translate that into what’s happening in our minds, it’s just a bunch of vowel sounds and flailing. We’re invested in this conclusion.

Over the last few weeks, HBO has released character portraits and the first trailer for the final season. I highly doubt we’ll get much more, but we can always hope.

To start things off, let’s take a look at the series of character portraits that HBO dropped on Twitter. Someone is definitely missing from these, *coughGendrycough*, but the internet has poured over them. One of the first things I noticed wasn’t the picture, but a certain sequence on EW’s Instagram of some of portraits.

If you click through, you’ll see Bran first, and on the next swipe, is the Night King.

Y’all, I know it’s a prevailing theory, but these portraits add something to that for me. From their posture to their placement. If Bran is the Night King, does that mean he went too far back and couldn’t return? Will there be a place in these final episodes where we see Bran make that jump when things get close during a battle?

This would also make sense in terms of the prophecy the Three-Eyed Raven told him:

“You will never walk again, but you will fly.”

This could be a nod to his warging and being the new Three-Eyed Raven, but I feel like he could mean that Bran as the Night King will fly Viserion this season. I’d be very surprised if the Night King had no connection to the Bran or the Stark family.

Another detail that stuck out to me was Sansa’s clothing.

We see her presumably hand over Winterfell to Daenerys when she arrives with Jon, but we all know Sansa well enough to know she’s not going all in just yet. No matter what Jon believes about this Targaryen. If you look closely at her clothing, though, it looks like dragon scales. I know she might not actually kill Drogon or Rhaegal, but the visual is enough.

You can take a look at all the portraits below as each character takes a seat on the Iron Throne.

Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter

 

In addition to the portraits, HBO also released the trailer. In it, Arya Stark is racing through the crypts of Winterfell, and she’s terrified. This is greatly at odds with her voiceover:

“I know Death. He’s got many faces. I look forward to seeing this one.”

Judging by the running, maybe it’s not a face she wants to see? Or maybe Arya is setting a trap much like she did for the Waif? All I know is Arya is holding a dragon glass dagger, and a few shots later we see Gendry walk beside a huge pile of dragon glass and his forge. I need this reunion like I need air.

Another important detail in the trailer, is we see Jon and Dany approach her remaining dragons. Could this mean we’ll see Jon Snow become a dragon rider this season?

A moment of relief is seeing Tormund and Beric Dondarrion safe after the fall of the Wall in season seven. Also in the trailer, there are several battle scenes from the Battle for Winterfell, along with the Unsullied awaiting battle. The Hound is surrounded by fire, and we see Cersei’s new warriors from Essos, the Golden Company arrive. Cersei herself looks sadden by something, and Jamie Lannister chooses his side once and for all:

“I promised to fight for the living. I intend to keep that promise.”

Our favorite Lannister, Tyrion, is only seen for a split second, though. It’s a shot we’ve seen before, of him looking up at the sky. Perhaps he’s watching Jon and Dany fly around Winterfell? What does this mean for the Hand of the Queen that we only see him for a brief moment?

Watch the trailer below and share your thoughts with us!

 

P.S. This gif gives me life. I’m pretending there’s not a sad ending here.

via GIPHY

 

Game of Thrones premieres Sunday, April 14, on HBO. Be sure to live tweet with us @WeSoNerdy!

‘Game of Thrones’ Season 8 Round-Up: Portraits, Trailers, and Theories! The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. 802 more words

Now, I said we’re looking forward to the final season, but when you translate that into what’s happening in our minds, it’s just a bunch of vowel sounds and flailing. We’re invested in this conclusion.

Over the last few weeks, HBO has released character portraits and the first trailer for the final season. I highly doubt we’ll get much more, but we can always hope.

To start things off, let’s take a look at the series of character portraits that HBO dropped on Twitter. Someone is definitely missing from these, *coughGendrycough*, but the internet has poured over them. One of the first things I noticed wasn’t the picture, but a certain sequence on EW’s Instagram of some of portraits.

If you click through, you’ll see Bran first, and on the next swipe, is the Night King.

Y’all, I know it’s a prevailing theory, but these portraits add something to that for me. From their posture to their placement. If Bran is the Night King, does that mean he went too far back and couldn’t return? Will there be a place in these final episodes where we see Bran make that jump when things get close during a battle?

This would also make sense in terms of the prophecy the Three-Eyed Raven told him:

“You will never walk again, but you will fly.”

This could be a nod to his warging and being the new Three-Eyed Raven, but I feel like he could mean that Bran as the Night King will fly Viserion this season. I’d be very surprised if the Night King had no connection to the Bran or the Stark family.

Another detail that stuck out to me was Sansa’s clothing.

We see her presumably hand over Winterfell to Daenerys when she arrives with Jon, but we all know Sansa well enough to know she’s not going all in just yet. No matter what Jon believes about this Targaryen. If you look closely at her clothing, though, it looks like dragon scales. I know she might not actually kill Drogon or Rhaegal, but the visual is enough.

You can take a look at all the portraits below as each character takes a seat on the Iron Throne.

Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter

Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter
Image Source: Twitter

 

In addition to the portraits, HBO also released the trailer. In it, Arya Stark is racing through the crypts of Winterfell, and she’s terrified. This is greatly at odds with her voiceover:

“I know Death. He’s got many faces. I look forward to seeing this one.”

Judging by the running, maybe it’s not a face she wants to see? Or maybe Arya is setting a trap much like she did for the Waif? All I know is Arya is holding a dragon glass dagger, and a few shots later we see Gendry walk beside a huge pile of dragon glass and his forge. I need this reunion like I need air.

Another important detail in the trailer, is we see Jon and Dany approach her remaining dragons. Could this mean we’ll see Jon Snow become a dragon rider this season?

A moment of relief is seeing Tormund and Beric Dondarrion safe after the fall of the Wall in season seven. Also in the trailer, there are several battle scenes from the Battle for Winterfell, along with the Unsullied awaiting battle. The Hound is surrounded by fire, and we see Cersei’s new warriors from Essos, the Golden Company arrive. Cersei herself looks sadden by something, and Jamie Lannister chooses his side once and for all:

“I promised to fight for the living. I intend to keep that promise.”

Our favorite Lannister, Tyrion, is only seen for a split second, though. It’s a shot we’ve seen before, of him looking up at the sky. Perhaps he’s watching Jon and Dany fly around Winterfell? What does this mean for the Hand of the Queen that we only see him for a brief moment?

Watch the trailer below and share your thoughts with us!

 

P.S. This gif gives me life. I’m pretending there’s not a sad ending here.

via GIPHY

 

Game of Thrones premieres Sunday, April 14, on HBO. Be sure to live tweet with us @WeSoNerdy!

‘Game of Thrones’ Season 8 Round-Up: Portraits, Trailers, and Theories! The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. 802 more words
trail.content:
The final season of Game of Thrones will premiere on April 14, and it’s the end of an era. Here’s what we know so far about the season eight!
External image

Image Source: Twitter

Along with everyone else in the world, we’re looking forward to the final season of Game of Thrones. It’s going to be six episodes of breathless action and a culmination of nine years of story-telling. It’s rare for a series to be able to have an endpoint in mind when they start, but that’s what Game of Thrones has done. Everything means something. If you rewatch, chances are you’ll find something new to support a theory you’re currently obsessing over.

Now, I said we’re looking forward to the final season, but when you translate that into what’s happening in our minds, it’s just a bunch of vowel sounds and flailing. We’re invested in this conclusion.

Over the last few weeks, HBO has released character portraits and the first trailer for the final season. I highly doubt we’ll get much more, but we can always hope.

To start things off, let’s take a look at the series of character portraits that HBO dropped on Twitter. Someone is definitely missing from these, *coughGendrycough*, but the internet has poured over them. One of the first things I noticed wasn’t the picture, but a certain sequence on EW’s Instagram of some of portraits.

If you click through, you’ll see Bran first, and on the next swipe, is the Night King.

Y’all, I know it’s a prevailing theory, but these portraits add something to that for me. From their posture to their placement. If Bran is the Night King, does that mean he went too far back and couldn’t return? Will there be a place in these final episodes where we see Bran make that jump when things get close during a battle?

This would also make sense in terms of the prophecy the Three-Eyed Raven told him:

“You will never walk again, but you will fly.”

This could be a nod to his warging and being the new Three-Eyed Raven, but I feel like he could mean that Bran as the Night King will fly Viserion this season. I’d be very surprised if the Night King had no connection to the Bran or the Stark family.

Another detail that stuck out to me was Sansa’s clothing.

We see her presumably hand over Winterfell to Daenerys when she arrives with Jon, but we all know Sansa well enough to know she’s not going all in just yet. No matter what Jon believes about this Targaryen. If you look closely at her clothing, though, it looks like dragon scales. I know she might not actually kill Drogon or Rhaegal, but the visual is enough.

You can take a look at all the portraits below as each character takes a seat on the Iron Throne.

“I know Death. He’s got many faces. I look forward to seeing this one.”

Judging by the running, maybe it’s not a face she wants to see? Or maybe Arya is setting a trap much like she did for the Waif? All I know is Arya is holding a dragon glass dagger, and a few shots later we see Gendry walk beside a huge pile of dragon glass and his forge. I need this reunion like I need air.

Another important detail in the trailer, is we see Jon and Dany approach her remaining dragons. Could this mean we’ll see Jon Snow become a dragon rider this season?

A moment of relief is seeing Tormund and Beric Dondarrion safe after the fall of the Wall in season seven. Also in the trailer, there are several battle scenes from the Battle for Winterfell, along with the Unsullied awaiting battle. The Hound is surrounded by fire, and we see Cersei’s new warriors from Essos, the Golden Company arrive. Cersei herself looks sadden by something, and Jamie Lannister chooses his side once and for all:

“I promised to fight for the living. I intend to keep that promise.”

Our favorite Lannister, Tyrion, is only seen for a split second, though. It’s a shot we’ve seen before, of him looking up at the sky. Perhaps he’s watching Jon and Dany fly around Winterfell? What does this mean for the Hand of the Queen that we only see him for a brief moment?

blog.name: atimefordirewolves
blog.title: "Have a biscuit, Potter"
blog.description: Sarah, 23, UK, Hufflepuff // I love Arya, Gendry, Theon, Dany, and Ginny Weasley with my whole moronic heart // #atimefordirewolves

summary: perfect arya? she is a great actress with more talent than those two Ds deserve, but she's come to look nothing like arya's...
question: perfect arya? she is a great actress with more talent than those two Ds deserve, but she's come to look nothing like arya's supposed to look like. of all the starks sophie's the only one matching her descriptions, and that only marginally bc of her startling eyes and marble-cut cheekbones. Usually tv and movies beautify their characters when adapting them, but got just said eff it and went the other way with the starks
answer:
Nahhhh I was talking her acting. Like, she has absolutely nailed Arya’s badassery but also has managed to work in the vulnerability and kindness that goes along with it. She’s a fantastic actress, and truly portrays and balances all these aspects of Arya extremely well. Looks wise I have to admit I don’t really care that much - she’s small and dark haired, and the girl they cast as Lyanna Stark looks strikingly similar to Maisie so that ‘Arya looks like Lyanna’ resemblance is there (which is arguably the most important point made about Arya’s appearance anyway).

What I meant was it’s so frustrating to see her bring to life Arya so perfectly in the way she acts, but then hasn’t read the books so doesn’t get all the nuances of Arya’s character - and often comes out and says stuff that us book readers are left to be like?? how?? can you be this perfect as arya?? but also still say this bollocks on the regular??

summary: What power? It had just made her a target of abuse. Her body, loved and protected by her family, her beauty that gave everyone...
body:
Ch. 5: The Lady of Winterfell

What power? It had just made her a target of abuse. Her body, loved and protected by her family, her beauty that gave everyone and herself pride, her name, had put her in some list for endless torment. Where was the Warrior? The Maiden? Father and Mother…these gods had abandoned her.

The latest update of Our Kingdom, Part One of Song of the Seven Kingdoms series.

AO3 account needed to access the fic.
